Short Description: Changes Date and Time Regarding Data used for Hand Counts
Implements HB3021 allowing submission of translated federal and statewide candidate statements and state measure arguments

Details:
The Secretary of State’s Translation Advisory Council will meet virtually on Wednesday, September 7, at 6:00 PM to review the translation process and to elect Council officers.

Wednesday, September 7, 2022, at 6:00 pm

•	Link for remote attendance
•	Agenda: 1) Welcome 2) Review Process Evaluation 3) Officer Elections

The Council is not required to take public testimony.

The Council was created to make recommendations to the Secretary on matters of translation, including the translation of voters’ pamphlets prior to each election. Council members review translated voter information to ensure accuracy and retain the original tone and meaning in a culturally appropriate manner. The Council is comprised of five members who are appointed at large and translator members who have proficiency in one of the most commonly spoken languages in Oregon.

Additional information can be found on the Translation Advisory Council website.

Short Description: Implements HB3021 allowing submission of translated federal and statewide candidate statements and state measure arguments
Details: Last day and time to offer comment to age​ncy: August 26, 2022, 5 p.m.

Pursuant to ORS 251.173, the Secretary of State’s Translation Advisory Council is convened to make recommendations to the Secretary on matters of translation including the translation of voters’ pamphlets prior to each election. The Council reviews translated voter information to ensure that translations are accurate and retain the original tone and meaning in a culturally appropriate manner. The Council is comprised of five members appointed at large and translator members who have proficiency in one of the most commonly spoken languages in Oregon.

The Council will meet virtually on Monday, August 15, at 6:00 PM via Microsoft Teams. The purpose of this meeting is to provide training on the process of reviewing professional translations and to nominate Council officers. The Council is not required to take public testimony. Additional information can be found on the Translation Advisory Council website.

•	Agenda: 1) Welcome 2) Training 3) Officer Nominations

Notice 1: Updates filing deadlines and implements legislative changes regarding candidate, and political party manuals and forms.
Notice 2: Updates signature verification deadlines and implements required legislative changes to the Recall
Manual.

​​​​​​​​Pursuant to ORS 250.125​, a five-member Financial Estimate Committee (FEC), composed of the Secretary of State, State Treasurer, Director of the Department of Revenue, Director of the Department of Administrative Services, and a local government representative must prepare an estimate of the financial impact of each measure to be voted on in the statewide elections. The estimate of financial impact will be printed in the Voters’ Pamphlet and on the ballot.

Short Description: Proposes amendments to the state Campaign Finance Manual
Details:
The amendments to this rule are needed to revise the procedural manual for campaign finance reporting requirements.
Further, these revisions are necessary to incorporate legislative mandates set out in HB 3291 which moved the date of
the regularly scheduled September election to August.

Short Description: Proposing a new rule related to campaign advertising disclosures required by ORS 260.266.
Details:
ORS 260.266, relating to campaign advertising disclosures takes effect on December 4, 2020. The Elections Division is undertaking the following, so that candidates, committees, the public, and others have information and guidance about how to comply with the new law:

A Temporary Rule is being adopted, which is effective immediately.

The process to adopt a Proposed Permanent Rule is also being initiated at the same time.

Comments can be submitted on the proposed permanent rule until 4:00 p.m. PT on Tuesday, January 26, 2021. Send comments to: elections.sos@oregon.gov.
The Rulemaking hearing on the proposed permanent rule will be held via Go To Meeting at 3:30 p.m. PT on January 25, 2021.  Information about how to attend the hearing is below:
Rulemaking Hearing related to ORS 260.266

Mon, Jan 25, 2021 3:30 PM - 4:30 PM (PST)

You can join from your computer, tablet or smartphone.

https://global.gotomeeting.com/join/278806973

United States: +1 (872) 240-3212

Access Code: 278-806-973

The text of both rules is currently the same. However, the permanent rule may be revised before it is adopted, depending on comments and other input received. 

The notices for both are located here: https://sos.oregon.gov/elections/Pages/rulemaking.aspx

The Public Records Advisory Council was created by Senate Bill 106 (2017). The Council works with the Advocate and the State Archives Division to study and make recommendations concerning the Advocate's role, as well as practices, procedures, exemptions, and fees related to public records.

Meeting Title: CANCELED: Sunshine Week Public Records Panel
Short Description: Hear from a panel of public records experts
Details: Hear from a panel of public records experts discussing pressing issues, moderated by the Acting Public Records Advocate, Todd Albert. Panelists represent both state agency public records officers and members of the records requester community. Issues to be discussed include the basics of the public records law, how to make an effective request, legislative updates and deadlines, fees and fee waivers/reductions, exemptions to disclosure, and employee resources.

Short Description: Welcome Immigrants into Citizenship at Naturalization Ceremony in State Capitol
Meeting Location: House Chamber, Oregon State Capitol, 900 Court St NE
Details:
To celebrate Oregon’s 160th birthday, the office of Secretary of State Dennis Richardson will host the 2nd annual Oregon State Capitol immigration and naturalization ceremony. 

This celebration of Oregon and its newest citizens is something that Secretary Richardson instituted during his 2nd month in office in February of 2017. This will be the second time in state history that a naturalization ceremony has been held in Oregon’s capitol building. This year’s ceremony will be held on February 14 at 12 p.m. in the House Chamber. A group of 15 individuals will take the oath to become American citizens.

Meeting Title: Oregon state Archives Annual Open House
Details:
A family-friendly event that gives Oregonians a close up view of the state’s historic records, including Oregon’s original Constitution.

In recognition of National Archives Month, the Oregon State Archives will hold its annual Open House on Saturday, October 6 from 10:00am to 3:00pm. The event will include a new gallery exhibit on the history of the Oregon State Fair. Light refreshments will be provided.

In addition, “behind the scenes” tours will be available of the State Archives records storage area so visitors can learn more about the Archives and its holdings. The 20-30 minute tour will provide an opportunity to see some of Oregon’s most significant historical documents, including the original Oregon Constitution.

Meeting Title: Administrative Rule Hearing on 2018 Election Manual Updates
Details:
The Oregon Elections Division released the election manual updates under consideration for the 2018 election cycle. After considering public feedback, the Elections Division intends to finalize manual changes effective January 1, 2018. 

Proposed changes include updating deadlines with 2018 dates, implementing election law changes passed during the 2016 and 2017 sessions, and adding clarifications to make the manuals more user-friendly. These changes will increase efficiency of Elections Division processes, thereby, saving taxpayer money. The changes will also equalize the playing field for grassroots advocates and minor parties.
For more information:
https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/ORSOS/bulletins/1c56b3b

Short Description: Expand public records training and add facilitated dispute resolution for public records requests.
Meeting Location: Oregon State Archives Building; 800 Summer St. NE
Details:
Rule Summary
The Secretary of State is launching the Oregon Access Project to improve public records access. As part of the project, the Archives Division will expand public records trainings for members of the public, media, state agencies, and local governments while also adding a new service:
facilitated dispute resolution for public records requests. This will maximize current staff expertise, use existing resources, and avoid
unnecessary duplication.

Meeting Title: Notice of Rulemaking Advisory Committee Meetings
Details:
The Rules Advisory Committee is being convened by the Secretary of State to discuss proposed administrative rules related to the Oregon Motor Voter Registration Process, under [HB 2177]. The Secretary will hold two committee meetings, each on a different day and time, to allow committee members more flexibility in participating Committee members may attend either meeting or both. Members of the public are welcome to attend either meetings. 

The Rules Advisory Committee will be asked for their feedback on various issues related to implementation and fiscal impacts of the bill the Secretary must consider for purposes of the fiscal impact statement associated with the adoption of the Oregon Motor Voter administrative rules.
ADA Contact: The meeting location is accessible to persons with disabilities. A request for an interpreter for the hearing impaired or for other accommodations for persons with disabilities should be made at least 48 hours before the meeting to (name and telephone/TTY number).

Meeting Title: Minority Voting Materials Task Force Meeting
Minority Voting Materials Task Force Meeting

Meeting Location: 255 Capitol St NE Ste 501 Rm 500B Public Service Building
Details:
SALEM – After each general election county elections officials are required to hand count a percentage of ballots and compare the hand counted tally of votes to the tally produced by the vote tally system for the same ballots.

In order to assist the Secretary of State in the random selection of the contests and precincts to be hand counted, the Secretary has appointed Vicki Berger, Kappy Eaton and Michael Hand to the Hand Count Advisory Committee. 

The Hand Count Advisory Committee will meet Friday, November 7, 2014, 9 am, Room 500B, Public Service Building 255 Capitol St NE Salem, 97302 to randomly select the contests and precincts to be hand counted. Interested parties are welcome to attend.

Meeting Title: Minority Voting Materials Task Force Meeting
Agenda Download: Minority Voting Materials Task Force Agenda 101614.docx (https://data.oregon.gov/views/gs36-7t8m/files/p-_90wXfGtolyRurimKJRVMycpd4GeKb21Sw-gxLO20?download=true&filename=Minority%20Voting%20Materials%20Task%20Force%20Agenda%20101614.docx)

Details:
After the FEC approves the draft statements, the statements will be filed with the Secretary of State, Elections Division.
The Secretary of State has scheduled a hearing to receive public comments on the draft financial impact statement for IRR 44 (Measure 92). If the statement receives comments during the public hearing, the FEC will review those comments and consider revisions to the statement:

Pursuant to ORS 250.131, a five-member Financial Estimate Committee (FEC), composed of the Secretary of State, State Treasurer, Director of the Department of Revenue, Director of the Department of Administrative Services, and a local government representative will meet to prepare an estimate of the financial impact of IRR 44 (Measure 92). Once completed, the financial estimate statement will be printed in the Voters’ Pamphlet and on the ballot.
